WWDC Plan

May 23, 2017

This will be my fifth WWDC as I had the opportunity to attend it since the 2012 edition (thanks Giovanni that gave me his ticket as he couldn‚Äôt attend). Then I won the lottery four times in a row from 2014 to 2017 ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

To be honest last year I transferred the ticket to my colleague @matax so he was able to attend his first WWDC, but I went to San Francisco anyway.

Bragging aside, I have plenty of expectations for this year regarding things to do, people to meet and questions to ask.

Take off is in less than two weeks üéâ

Arrival

This year WWDC moved back to San Jose after many years being held in San Francisco, it‚Äôs a new location for me and I‚Äôve never been there, so I don‚Äôt know basically anything: that‚Äôs great!

Apple announced WWDC in mid February (earlier than usual) so I took the opportunity to book flights and hotel immediately, hoping to win the lottery, but also knowing that there would have been other conferences to attend like AltConf, Layers and CocoaConf Next Door. I‚Äôm usually on budget and this was a pleasant surprise: everything did cost approximately 50% less than usual ‚Äî 659‚Ç¨ for 6 nights (including taxes) and 596‚Ç¨ for the intercontinental flights. I‚Äôm going to flight Lufthansa, United and Canada Airlines, not the best options, but surely the cheapest I could find ‚Äî hoping to avoid the infamous cabin drag. I wasn‚Äôt able to find an itinerary to land directly at San Jose airport as it would have been closer.

The first night I‚Äôll stay in a cheap hotel nearby the Airport in South San Francisco as I‚Äôm going to collapse immediately and sleep at least twelve hours.

For the following nights I‚Äôve chosen a motel really close to the McEnery Convention Center where WWDC and most of the third party events are being held. Reducing commuting time during the week is compulsory to to enjoy it at best.

Flights

I‚Äôll take off from Verona - VRN on Saturday 3 at 10 AM to land in San Francisco - SFO on the same day at 7:45 PM after a pause in Frankfurt am Main - FRA for approximately 6 hours. I hope to visit Frankfurt‚Äôs city center and grab some Br√§twurst with Wei√übier.


I‚Äôm coming from Italy so I have a long flight ahead. Those are the things I‚Äôm bringing with me in cabin, if no new bans are enforced:

  • B&O H6 rev 2 - I don‚Äôt have noise canceling headphones as I don‚Äôt travel much, but those will do.
  • AirPods, but I‚Äôm really scared to lose them if I fell asleep.
  • Bundled Lightning to Headphone Jack adapter.
  • Power Brick.
  • iPhone 7.
  • USB-A to Lightning cable.
  • Lightning splitter to charge and listen at the same time.
  • MacBook if allowed.
  • USB-C to Lightning cable to connect to the mac.
  • A pen to compile the immigration form.
  • Passport.
  • Apple Watch.
  • N26 Black Credit Card.
  • A small Pillow.
  • A hoodie.
  • Comfortable shoes.

The Masterplan

For me it‚Äôs people first, tech second. Every choice I make is based on who I can meet and what I can get from the available events. There‚Äôs only one week like this each year so you should consider every opportunity and be assured: you can sleep later on your way back home.

This is my personal list of things I‚Äôd like to do.

Sunday

I plan to move to San Jose early in the morning, check-in at the hotel, eventually go to the Apple Store to let them check an iPhone 5s with the battery that‚Äôs growing large and bending the screen, then pick up the WWDC badge.

At 5 pm I‚Äôm going to watch App: The Human Story, a Documentary Screening Presented by AltConf & Layers. I already got the $25 ticket and you should too as 100% of the proceedings will go to App Camp for Girls. You can even watch the trailer online.

Sunday night: go to bed at a decent time to reduce the jet lag and prepare for the Keynote queue.

Monday

Early morning: Spend few hours queuing around the McEnery Convention Center, waiting for the WWDC Keynote to start, trying to get a decent place in the auditorium. In my useless experience, I knew that even if you showed up at 6 AM you‚Äôll easily enter in Presidio. New location and everything is unexpected. If I cannot sleep I may even show up really early. Breakfast is usually served inside the auditorium.

Morning: enjoy the Keynote at 10 AM!

Lunch time: find the room with ethernet cables and download the newly released stuff: Xcode, iOS and macOS betas, documentation, release notes and API differences. Bring your own ethernet dongle as there are chances that you won‚Äôt find the adapter suiting your computer port attached to the cables. Don‚Äôt even try to download stuff on WiFi as it‚Äôs usually unreliable.

Early afternoon: watch the State of the Union. If rumors are true and this year we‚Äôll get new hardware announced in the keynote during the morning, the State of the Union will be the real keynote for developers to highlight the news. Don‚Äôt miss it.

Afternoon: listen to Accidental Tech Podcast live at @ AltConf at 5 pm.

Evening: show up for the Relay FM WWDC meet-up @ the Museum of Quilts and Textiles at 7 pm.

Night: I‚Äôm waiting for the Beard Bash tickets to go on sale, hopefully I‚Äôll be able to get one. I‚Äôve also requested an invite for the Firebase + Fabric party but I‚Äôm no one and probably my request won‚Äôt be even considered. Alternatively I may also collapse on the bed ‚Äî let‚Äôs wait and see.

Tuesday to Friday

Sessions and labs. After the keynote the full schedule will go online without placeholders concealing newly announced stuff. Take 10 minutes and plan your conference choosing which sessions to attend, which one to skip and stream later (it‚Äôs OK!), but most importantly when the labs you need to go will happen. I already have a small list of questions I‚Äôd like to ask to Apple engineers, but usually as soon as the new APIs are published that list grows exponentially. I usually choose to skip very crowded and mainstream sessions hold in the biggest rooms like What‚Äôs new in Swift, What‚Äôs new in Auto Layout and Getting Started with Swift as for example Swift is now open source so we already know what‚Äôs coming in Swift 4; more advanced sessions or less mainstream ones are more intresting to me as eventually you‚Äôll get invaluable feedback directly after the presentation if you place your questions to the hosts.

Lunch sessions - I usually keep an eye on those as they are inspiring and motivational: usually you‚Äôll be able to be part of something really unique. Those are not streamed nor recorder, so it‚Äôs a lifetime opportunity. I still remember the ones with J. J. Abrams telling about Bad Robot, one with Star Wars authors and troopers, one where @plutokiller detailed his reasons to remove Pluto from the list of planets ‚Äî way before the New Horizons probe took some amazing photos.

I hope the catering will be different and lunch boxes will be edible for the first time.

Get Togethers recently Apple started planning pop-up informal events during the conference to let you meet with like-minded developers and Apple experts for engaging and motivating conversations around specific topics. Keep an eye on them.

Tuesday

Evening: The Talk Show Live at 6 pm ‚Äî tickets still need to go on sale and I‚Äôm hoping to get one (I‚Äôm relying on Overcast push notifications for new episodes and following @gruber on Twitter). Apple Executives were John Gruber‚Äôs special guests during the last two years: Phil Shiller and Craig Federighi. Also interesting (and I already have a ticket) is the Swift Panel with Chris Lattner, Jesse Squires, JP Simard, Kamilah Taylor and Kevin Ballard at 6 pm ‚Äî location still unknown but will be in San Jose. I‚Äôm subscribed to the Swift Unwrapped podcast hosted by Squires and Simard to follow along swift evolution.

Wednesday

Evening: I got a ticket for the Better Elevation Extravaganza with news and music. There‚Äôs also another funding event for App Camp for Girls. I‚Äôve attended it last year but I have to admit I‚Äôm not able to keep up with the songs played by James Dempsey and the Breakpoints (tech and developer friendly). Also the event has different ticket tiers with a VIP reserved area that you can join performing a substantial donation.

Thursday

Evening: (usually) the WWDC beer bash hosted by Apple, with music, food and beer.

Friday

Most people leave early but sessions and labs usually go on until 5 pm. Be sure to don‚Äôt miss them as most advanced topics will be held during those final hours, like the legendary Crusty 2015 and 2016 sessions.

Bonus

I would love to have a sneak peak at Apple Park but it seems difficult right now as most employees are still working at 1 Infinite Loop. Maybe Apple will organise something there, like the beer bash, but I‚Äôm not holding my breath.

I‚Äôve already been inside Apple‚Äôs current headquarters at 1 Infinite Loop two years ago thanks to @filippobiga. If you are interested and know someone that works there ask him/her if you could visit the mothership. Don‚Äôt expect much more than a meal at Cafe Mac and some good talks in the central park. Invaluable for a long time Mac lover.

Company Store, in the convention center usually there‚Äôs a pop up company store where you can buy pricey Apple branded t-shirts, hats, hoodies, pens, bottles and not so much more. The same stuff is usually available at the company store at 1 Infinite Loop. Keep in mind that common sizes will be on fire on Tuesday and Wednesday. Don‚Äôt expect to find something different from XXXL hoodies later in the week.

San Francisco. If you‚Äôve never been there you can consider a visit taking the public transport Caltrain: it‚Äôs just an hour and fifteen minutes from San Jose.

WWDC.family app is an easy way to connect with other developers during WWDC.

Parties is a great app to keep up with the events organised by third parties during WWDC week.

People I‚Äôd like to meet

  • Federico Viticci as fellow Italian fan of MacStories and Connected to say ciao again after a year.
  • Stephen Hackett and Mike Hurley of Relay FM as they fulfill most of my spare time with podcasts. It‚Äôs a tradition as I first met them when they were part of the 5by5 network.

  • Marco, John and Casey - a truly great trio that shares with me at least two hours every week!
  • John Gruber, I‚Äôd love to say hi.
  • Apple Execs ‚Äì specially Craig Federighi ‚Äì Hair Force One. You know‚Ä¶ selfies.
  • Many developers I met in the last few years.
  • Apple employees as their work is totally fascinating to me.
  • You - I‚Äôm eager to know new people every year!

Staying

Few non obvious things I‚Äôm bringing with me: Imodium (after a memorable debacle two years ago), earplugs as you never know where and when you‚Äôll end up sleeping, multiple USB charger with USB-A and C, USA to Italy plug converters, MacBook power brick with USB-C cable, Apple Watch cable, spare dollars for hotel tips.

I won‚Äôt bring with me the electric shaver as my model doesn‚Äôt support 50Hz ‚Äî 110V power supply and it will be so slow that will grab and pull the hairs instead of trimming them. I usually remember it too late and I‚Äôm forced to buy razors at the mall like an animal.

Leaving

I‚Äôm leaving on Saturday morning from San Francisco ‚Äì SFO to enjoy a final evening with friends on Friday. The trip will be quite long as I‚Äôm heading to Toronto ‚Äì YYZ, my first time in Canada, then again Frankfurt ‚Äì FRA and finally back to Verona ‚Äì VRN totalling 20 hours between first take off and final landing. An hour driving will bring be back home in Trento1 with my family üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüë¶‚Äçüë¶.

I look forward to have an amazing week and meet you if you are there too.
